node.title: Christmas shoppers beware: Police issue warning amid increase in scam puppy sales
node.description: The scams are often offering sought after breeds such as English bulldogs, huskies, Staffordshire bull terriers, maltese and toy poodles.
node.content: ["Police are warning people looking to buy a puppy over the Christmas period to be careful amid an increase in scam sales online.\u00a0", "Wellington Constable Kylee Coubrough says police have noticed an increase in people selling puppies online which don't exist.\u00a0", "Coubrough said the majority of the scam sales are done through trading sites or fake websites and often include sought after breeds including English bulldogs, huskies, Staffordshire bull terriers, maltese and even toy poodles.", "She said the sellers claim the puppies are fully vaccinated and toilet trained. The buyer is likely not allowed to view the puppy before purchase and the fake sellers often claim they have their own delivery services.\u00a0", "\"These sellers are also making 'change of ownership' documents for each purchased puppy, which is not a thing in New Zealand,\" Constable Coubrough warned.\u00a0", "\"Neither is a breeder registering the puppy before you get it... all these things are red flags. People need to be doing some extensive research on puppy sellers before paying money to anyone.\"", "Police recommend the following safety tips if you're considering buying a puppy online:", "Remember, if something illegal is happening now, call 111. If it's already happened, you can provide information via the Police non-emergency number 105.\u00a0 \u00a0"]
